newsitem.title: INDIA: India's soybean trade unhappy on new import rules.
newsitem.headline: India's soybean trade unhappy on new import rules.

text.p: A representative group of India's soymeal traders on Tuesday expressed concern over the government's decision to continue a ban on oilseeds imports in the new trade policy.
The government earlier this month announced the Export-Import (Exim) Policy for 1997-2002 in which it allowed only the state-run agencies to import oilseeds.
The Soybean Processors' Association of India (SOPA) said that allowing private traders to import oilseeds would have helped to use the idle refining capacity, which is currently more than 60 percent.
SOPA is the chief soymeal trade body in the central state of Madhya Pradesh, the hub of India's soybean industry, which contributes nearly 80 percent of the country's soybean output.

"It is beyond doubt and more prudent to allow raw material import rather than continuing the present policy of importing oil, which is a finished product," said Davish Jain, chairman of SOPA in a statement.
"SOPA had expected a fair treatment in the Exim Policy in view of the large export earnings by the industry which is otherwise suffering from low capacity utilisation," Jain said.
India imports more than one million tonnes of edible oil annually. Industry officials expect edible oil imports to rise to 1.5 million tonnes in 1996/97 (November-October) from 1.2 million tonnes.
